4427830/4348120/4455921.title: Charms
4427830/4348120/4455921.text:
CharmsIt is said that if a person had a pain in his tooth and if he put a little bit of tobacco in it, it would cure it.  Other people say that if you got a little piece of cotton and warmed it and put it to your tooth it would be another cure for it.  It is said that ferrets leavings cure for the chin cough.  Other people say that asses milk is another cure for that cough.  Some people say that if you boil seven tops of nettles and drink the juice of them it would be a cure for a sore throat.  People say that if you find a little hole of water in a stone without looking for it, it would be a cure for a wart.  Other people say that if you get a black snail and kill him and put it three times on the wart and hang him on a bush when the snail would be weathered away the wart would be gone.  People say that if you had a corn and get a little bit of bacon and put it in your sock over the corn, it would be cure for it.  Other people say that if you went in your feet spreading turf in a bog it would be another cure for corns.
(continues on next page)

4427830/4348123/4455924.title: Charms
4427830/4348123/4455924.text:
It is said that if you cut the tops of seven nettles and boil them because it is said that juice of them is good for a sore throat. It is said that if you ask a man with a white horse had he any cure for the chin cough and what ever he will say is good for the chin cough. It is also said if you had warts on your hand and to get a snail whe [sic] you would not be looking for it and to rub him on the wart and stick him in a black thorn bush and the wart will wither. It is also said that if you will get a limestone with a hole in it, it is said that it is another cure for a wart but you must go to that stone every Thursday to wash it. If you had a sprained foot to go and tell the weaver about it but not to ask the thread. The weaver will put a lot of knots on the thread, and he will put the thread on the sprained foot.J. 4427830/4348126/4455925.title: Charms
4427830/4348126/4455925.text: It is said that if you meet a man with a white horse and to ask a cure off him for the chin cough anything he would tell you would cure you. Then to leave him on a white thorn bush and according to how the snail would be weathering the wart would be going.  If you make a worm knot over a calf that is sick he would get cured. 4427830/4348137/4455937.title: Charms
4427830/4348137/4455937.text: Old people have a lot if charms. If you get a bit of meat and put it in a paper and if you had a wart and rub the bit of meat of it once a day and when the meat is gone the wart will be gone. If you had a cold and get a frog and let him down your back the cold will go. If you had the chin cough and go to a man with a white horse anything he says will cure you. If you drink half the asses milk when you have a cold the cold will go. People say that if you get a Muglogh Nut and keep it you would never get a tooth ache. I was looking for nuts and I got one. But also I cracked it and would you believe what ti done. It knocked my tooth clean out. From that day to this I had a tooth ache. If I kept the Muglogh Nut I would never have a tooth ache.Charles A. 4427956/4360932/4465313.title: Charms
4427956/4360932/4465313.text: There is a pretty general belief in charms in this district."Dust in the eye" charm.  Patrick McCann, lived for some years before he died, at Lisloughna about one mile to the east of the school.  He lived formerly, at Lavey, which is a village two miles east of Charlestown, on the Charlestown to Ballaghaderin road.  He seems to have some peculiar charm for taking a dust out of the eye.  I knew him to remove a dust from the eye of a pupil, who came to school about nineteen twenty-three.  The boy, Thomas Price, was suffering for a few days with a dust in the eye.  finally McCann was sent for.  Here is what he did according to the boy:- "He put me sitting on a chair over at the bed; then he got a cup of cold water and placed it in front of him on the table.  After a while, he said it was out of the eye.  He showed me the dust in the water."A woman by name Mrs Peyton commonly called 'Máire bán" lived at Cloonfinisk, she had a charm for removing dust from the eye.  People wrote to her from England.  She worked some charm by which she removed dust from the eye of a person over in England.  She cured several people at home.This woman had also a charm for head - fever.

4428055/4373222/4466946.text:
There is a man in Knockmore and his name is Oliver Rider. He has a charm to cure a sore neck. He leaves his hand on the person's neck once a day for three days then the soreness goes and then the neck is cured. He has this cure because he is the seventh son.When the people are churning they put coals and a grain of salt under the churn for fear the fairies would bring the milk and butter. If anybody comes in while while they they are churning and takes a coal out of the fire they will have the butter with them. If a stranger comes in and he does not churn a while he will have the butter with him.
(continues on next page)

4493697/4411931/4524776.title: Orthaí
4493697/4411931/4524776.text: Tá cuid mhór órthaí ag na sean-daoine fa'n áit seo. Ní thabharann na dochtúirí nó an Eaglais isteach(?) dóbhtha acht tá léas ionnta má bhíonn muinghín ag an té atá dá bhfághail go dtiocfaidh biseach air. Tá órtha ag na daoine do chuid mhór rudaí mar órtha an leónta(?), órtha an déididh(?), órtha an ruaidh, órtha dúlagan, órtha an chait bhrághaid.Tá cuid mhór daoine a bhfuil órtha an ruaidh aca. Gheibh siad giota beag ime agus téigheann siad ar a gcuid glúna agus deir siad focla no paidreacha eighinteacht os a chionn. Nuair a bhéadh an duine a mbéadh na órthaí seo aca ag fághail bháis thiocfadh leis an órtha a thabhairt do dhuine eighinteacht eile.

4666574/4663294/4668035.text: At twelve o'clock at night commence making butter in a bottle. The person who sets this charm while fasting gives piece of the butter next morning to the sick person while fasting after saying some prayers over him.It is very unlucky to pull dandelion from the roots during May. 4672088/4669106/4678465.title: A Charm
4672088/4669106/4678465.text: My Grandmother has a charm for a head-ache. Every one around the village go to her and get cured. She can tell whither you have a big pain or not. She knows how many inches your head is opened with pain. She gets a piece of tape and measures your head from the back to your nose, and from the top of your head, to your chin. She repeats strange words while doing so. There are special days for getting cured, namely Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. You have to go those days to get your head measured. The cure will not be made, unless  you give her some payment such as tobacco, sweets or oranges or anything. "Some that come to her," she says "their heads are like sponge with pain."

Folk Prayers - Charms.There are no folk prayers existing in this district but charms are by no means gone.(1) The "straining thread," a thin thread of hemp made with certain prayers, now lost, is usually kept for a cure for sprains + strains Not every one made them, a local weaver named Murray used to make them. He is dead thirty years or so.(2) Cows put out to grass in summer still wear a piece of red cloth tied around the tail. This was for the "evil eye."(3) When a calf dies from black leg a knuckly bone is cut out and put in the  chimney. This prevents the other stock from taking the complaint.(4) The thorn of a gooseberry bush is picked off and pointed nine times at a stye in the eye without touching the eye. It is believed in very much.(5) The seventh son had the power of curing ringworm. Now people know of this power in the child was to place a live worm in the child's hand. If the cure was present the worm convulsed and died A gold wedding ring was often worn for the same cure.

CharmsMany people were able to set charms long ago. Dan Dore of Ballyowen used cure many people by charms. When dogs used go mad and bite people Dan Dore had a charm that would cure the bitten person. My father was bitten by a mad dog and he was cured by a charm set by Dore. Dan Dore used set the charm by keeping his own cows milk inside and letting it set to make butter of it. The person who wanted to be cured should go to him three mornings fasting and take a bit of the butter. In a bottle he used make this butter and he put no salt in it.He used not charge any money but he used tell the person he cured to give a few pence to the next poor man he would meet. He used to say words over the butter. Children that were bitten by a mad dog used go mad and if they did not seek a cure by a charm it was customary to smother them between two ticks of feathers.Ita Sexton

Local Charms.(The following cure charms were given to me by Michael Connolly, Baranique, Carrickerry, aged 70 years, who spent his life in the locality).For the cure of farsi in horses, people of this locality believe in charms as cures.  There was a man living near Rathkeale some years ago, who practiced these "cures", and to whom some people brought their horses.  His name was Delmege, and was a Palatine.Some ten or fifteen years ago, a man named Wrenn of Knockfinisk, Athea, took a horse suffering from farsi to this Mr. Delmege.  it was necessary in order to work the "cure", that the horse should be taken to him nine mornings in succession, and before the sun would rise.  This man of the Wrenns "who lives yet" took his horse for nine mornings before sunrise.  After the first or second morning the horse used to trot away before him, as is he were anxious, and in a hurry for the journey.On the final morning when the "cure" was completed Mr. Delmege told Wrenn that he should now "put" the ailment on some other animal, and asked him what animal in his home should he put it on.

5009170/4993999/5103412.text: There is a man living in Longford called Mr. Lloyd, he has a charm for curing warts. 5009180/4994959/5105935.title: Charms
5009180/4994959/5105935.text: People have the cure for a lot of ailments and they are called charms. Some people have the cure of a thorn in the hand. If you have a thorn in your hand they will say a prayer over the hand, and they say it will come out itself. But you must have belief in the cure.The cure for a sty is to get ten gooseberry thorns, and throw away the tenth one. And for nine mornings throw away each one of the thorns.   Some people can cure ailments when others can't.

5009180/4994961/5105941.title: Charms
5009180/4994961/5105941.text: A cure for a sore throat was fill a stocking full of salt and tie it round the neck.  A cure for an ear-ache is a little bag or pad of hot bran placed to the ear.   A cure for tooth-ache is to take a straw from the Crib and keep it, and rub it to the back of the tooth that is painful.    A cure for a thorn is soap and sugar.   A cure for whooping cough is to put on a horse's winkers and lead the person that has it in and out through the pig-stye three times or under a horse's belly.

5009019/4977900/5115713.text: Long ago in Ireland the people used to be able to take away other peoples butter by charms. 4921630/4886411/5168173.title: Spells - Charms
4921630/4886411/5168173.text: Some of the old people could work charms to stop bleeding or a thing like that. They didn't see anything wrong in that, as 'twas for a good purpose. They used to do something, and say some prayers. 'Twas done to myself, I suppose it is twenty years ago. I cut my hand badly at a thrashing and I thought I couldn't stop the bleeding at all. John Hurry was there, and I knew he had the spin. I showed him the hand. "Look" said I. I didn't ask him do anything, for you know they wouldn't like to have their power spoken about at all. He took my hand and pressed it and the bleeding stopped on the spot. John Hurry was my uncle. He died about fifteen years ago and he over 88. Curly [?] Bán had it too.

4921630/4886412/5168175.title: Spells - Charms
4921630/4886412/5168175.text: Dan the Captain's father was one day making a kitch, and he cut his hand badly between the thumb and the first finger. It was bleeding very badly and late that night they came here to my grandfather to stop it. We were in bed, and we heard the dog barking. We had a very cross dog and he wouldn't let them in beyond the gate, so they called. My father the Lord have mercy on him, went out. We all got up. My grandfather came on his knees, and having taken the cloth off the hand he said something in Irish, and breathed on the cut. That stopped it. 5162149/5158926/5197955.text: Long ago some of the old people had power to do some wonderful thing and these powers were called charms. Micilín Burke was  tramp travelling around the Country and he always had a twinty  or thirty dogs following him around from house to house looking for alms for me brothers as he used to call them. Mrs. Nugent, Seskin Carrick-on-Suir had a charm to stop blood. Before a person would have a charm another person should send some words written on piece of paper and the person should not know who send the piece of paper. If a dog bit a person the old people used to catch the dog and they used to pull a rib  of hair from the dog and put it on the cut and it is said that the cut wouldn’t ever fester. When a man would go to town and when he would take some drink he would say the day after that he would like to get a rib from the dog that bit him yesterday.
